# 總裁報告

2016年的全球政經舞台上「黑天鵝」身影頻仍，英國脫歐公投和美國總統大選結果固然令各種民調淪為笑柄，但更出乎意料的卻是金融市場的反應。以美國大選為例，特朗普當選消息令美股三大指數的期貨在開市前急挫，但開市不久美股指數隨即反彈，此後凱歌高奏，屢創新高。連串事件，凸顯了傳統智慧和思維對預測市場能力的局限性，也標誌着未來環球局勢發展的重大不確定性。

過去一年，多項主要金融數據都反映市場情緒異常敏感：美國十年期國庫債券收益率在7月跌至1.36厘歷史低位後，在美國總統大選後的12月中旬飆升至2.6厘。反映美元兌一籃子貨幣走勢的美匯指數在年底升至14年高位；紐約原油期貨價格由年初每桶26美元低位反彈至年底的54美元。本港股市方面，恒生指數全年微升86點，但期內峰谷差逾6,000點。外圍形勢驚濤駭浪，更形金融體系尤其是貨幣和銀行體系穩定的重要和可貴。

2016年1月，國際對沖基金部署狙擊人民幣和港元的傳言甚囂塵上，人心虛怯。金管局迅即向市場發放明確、堅定的訊息，我們絕對有信心、有能力捍衛聯匯制度和香港的金融體系穩定，適時穩住了市場信心。綜觀2016年全年，港元長時間貼近強方兌換保證。由於銀行體系資金非常充裕，即使去年12月和今年3月美國聯儲局加息，對港元利率和匯率並未有明顯的即時影響。

香港銀行體系繼續穩步發展，去年整體貸款錄得6.5%溫和增長，資產質素保持良好，不良貸款比率維持在0.85%的健康水平，遠低於2000年以來約2%的長期平均水平。銀行體系的資本充足率和流動性比率均保持在高於法定要求的高水平。在樓宇按揭業務方面，經過七輪逆周期措施，新造住宅物業按揭平均成數從2009年9月的64%下降至2016年底的51%，平均供款與入息比率也從2010年8月的41%下降至2016年底的34%，為樓市周期一旦逆轉而令銀行體系受到衝擊時，提供了所需的緩衝。金管局會繼續密切留意樓市的發展，因應周期變化而採取合適措施，以保持銀行體系穩定。

進一步強化銀行體系穩定的立法工作去年取得令人鼓舞的進展。優化存款保障制度和針對金融機構「大得不能倒」風險的兩條法例，及時在上屆立法會任期屆滿前順利通過。前者加快存款保障金的發放速度，簡化發放程序，有助加強存戶對銀行體系的信心；後者則為包括銀行在內的金融機構建立處置機制，防範這些機構一旦倒閉而引發的系統性金融風險，並盡量避免動用公帑為它們「包底埋單」。金管局已在今年4月1日設立處置機制辦公室，落實執行法例的要求和跟進工作。

銀行業素有「百業之母」之稱，是實體經濟和普羅市民日常生活倚重的儲蓄、支付渠道和信貸來源。年內，部分中小企業界代表反映融資有困難。金管局即時與銀行界溝通，希望銀行在維持審慎風險管理的情況下，盡可能為中小企的營運和發展繼續提供資金支援。我們又透過轄下香港按揭證券公司，加強向工商界推廣政府的「中小企融資擔保計劃」，並與銀行業界緊密溝通，以釋除疑慮、釐清誤解及理順處理壞帳的索償程序，從而提高銀行參與該計劃的意願。多管齊下，收到了一定成效，根據金管局對銀行進行的調查，中小企整體信貸額度在去年保持平穩，超過九成企業的信貸額度得以維持甚至增加。同時，「中小企融資擔保計劃」的申請數字亦明顯上升。

近年來金管局大力推動普及金融，就是考慮到基本銀行服務已是營商和日常生活不可或缺的環節。去年當我們得知有些海外公司和初創企業在香港開戶遇到困難後，旋即展開跟進工作，與多個國際商會和企業協會聯繫，並跟銀行業界深入溝通，對症下藥。去年9月我向香港所有銀行簽發通告，闡釋應如何理解金管局針對反洗錢和恐怖分子資金籌集活動的「風險為本」監管原則，如何將這項原則應用在開戶申請和對現有客戶的盡職審查措施上，強調銀行不應對所有客戶採用「一刀切」的要求和程序。經我們與銀行和商界協商後，企業開戶情況有所改善，但仍有進步空間，這也是我們今年工作重點之一。

普及金融還涉及銀行分行服務的覆蓋面。金管局一直鼓勵銀行在營商圖利之餘，也要顧及市民的基本銀行服務需要。金融科技一日千里，銀行提供服務的渠道也更趨多元化。除了日益普及的網上銀行服務外，去年多家銀行紛紛推出流動銀行車或視像櫃員機服務，提供較傳統櫃員機更貼身、更全面的銀行服務。在我們的推動下，多家銀行也計劃在偏遠地區設立實體分行，加強對當區居民的服務。

金融中心的發展就如逆水行舟，因此，金管局多年來不斷為香港金融業發展尋求新的契機，開拓新的領域。2016年可說是成果豐碩的一年，當中又以金融科技(Fintech)和基建融資為亮點。

在金融科技方面，香港的零售支付服務在2016年進入新時代。金管局去年發出13個儲值支付工具牌照，通過發牌和恒常監管制度為零售支付服務創造有利的營商環境，配以一系列公眾教育宣傳，讓消費者在享受新科技帶來的便捷之餘，權益也得到合理保障。

此外，去年3月金管局成立了金融科技促進辦公室，以此平台推動與銀行業相關的金融科技發展。幾個月間，我們推出多項新猷，包括「網絡防衛計劃」(Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative)，為強化銀行體系網絡安全建立風險評估、資訊共享和人才培訓三足鼎立的新平台。我們並與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作，開展分布式分類帳技術(distributed ledger technology)專項研究，探討該技術在香港銀行業應用的可行性，並在應科院設立金融科技創新中心(Fintech Innovation Hub)，為銀行業界和金融科技界提供技術支援。金管局的銀行監管部門還設立「金融科技監管沙盒」(Fintech Supervisory Sandbox)，讓銀行在較小和可控範圍內測試新技術的應用，為新產品、新服務的開發提速。自去年9月至今年3月，已有6家銀行共14項新技術項目使用沙盒進行測試，部分項目亦已相繼推出市場，為市民帶來更多金融科技的新產品。

世界各地對基建融資的需求巨大，特別是「一帶一路」倡議提出以來，基建融資更成中外矚目的議題。香港是亞洲的國際金融中心，在基建融資領域極具優勢。去年7月金管局成立了基建融資促進辦公室(Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office，簡稱IFFO)，搭建一個嶄新和獨特的平台，匯聚60多家世界級的多邊機構、機構投資者、銀行、保險公司和其他金融機構、基建項目的建設和營運方、各類專業機構等，就基建投融資課題互通訊息、交流經驗、尋求合作機會。IFFO成立至今已舉辦十多場大型會議、研討會和工作坊，金管局並分別與國際金融公司(International Finance Corporation)、全球基礎設施中心(Global Infrastructure Hub)、國家開發銀行(China Development Bank)和中國進出口銀行(The Export-Import Bank of China)簽署了共同促進基建投融資活動的《諒解備忘錄》。起步時間雖然不長，但為香港未來作為基建投融資中心奠下堅實的基礎。

拆牆鬆綁是提升競爭力的不二法門。年內，金管局積極參與和支援特區政府修訂稅務條例，向在港經營集團內部財資業務的企業提供有利的稅務環境。我們並積極接觸跨國企業，吸引它們來港發展或擴充企業財資活動，藉此進一步強化香港金融市場的功能。

去年的離岸人民幣市場處於調整期。受市場波動和對人民幣匯率預期等因素影響，全球離岸人民幣資金池規模普遍收縮。儘管如此，香港仍穩執離岸人民幣業務的牛耳，保持全球最大的人民幣資金池，經香港結算的人民幣維持在日均約8,600億元人民幣高位。為進一步優化香港離岸人民幣市場的流動性安排，去年10月我們將一級流動性提供行由7家增至9家，支援雙邊流動資金的總額度由原來的140億元人民幣增至180億元，確保在離岸人民幣市場資金出現緊絀的情況下，仍可保持市場有序運作。去年12月股票市場「深港通」開通，令香港的人民幣業務再添動力。金管局亦正與內地有關當局研究「債券通」方案，進一步便利兩地投資者參與債券市場，並優化債券市場基礎設施的聯繫。

儘管去年全球投資環境充斥着各種不穩因素，但有賴於過去一段時間所採取的多項防禦性部署，外匯基金去年錄得681億港元投資收入。自1994年以來外匯基金的複合年度投資回報率達4.8%，高於同期2.1%的本地通脹率。

外匯基金將繼續推動多元化投資，包括進一步擴展資產類別，加大對於信貸資產、抵禦通脹類投資產品和新興市場的投資。而作為多元化投資旗艦的「長期增長組合」，透過私募股權和房地產項目等投資於另類資產。該組合自2009年啟動以來一直保持不俗的成績，成立至今的平均內部回報率年率約12%，而隨着政府「未來基金」部分投放於該組合，我們加快了投資步伐，去年底「長期增長組合」的資產規模約1,818億港元，已批出但未提取作投資的總額約1,338億港元。外匯基金將繼續恪守「保本先行、長期增值」的投資策略，在保持充裕的流動性和備用資金的前提下，尋求長遠穩定的回報。
en:
# Chief Executive’s Report

In 2016, the global political and economic stage was frequently visited by "black swan" events. The outcomes of the Brexit referendum and the US presidential election not only rendered various public opinion polls a laughingstock, but even more surprising was the reaction of the financial markets. Take the US election as an example: news of Trump’s victory caused the futures of the three major US stock indices to plunge before the market opened, but shortly after opening, the indices rebounded and subsequently surged triumphantly, repeatedly reaching new highs. This series of events highlighted the limitations of traditional wisdom and thinking in predicting markets, and also signaled significant uncertainty in the future development of the global landscape.

Over the past year, several major financial indicators reflected an unusually sensitive market sentiment: the yield on the US 10-year Treasury bond fell to a historic low of 1.36% in July, then surged to 2.6% in mid-December after the US presidential election. The US Dollar Index, which tracks the performance of the dollar against a basket of currencies, rose to a 14-year high by year-end; New York crude oil futures rebounded from a low of US$26 per barrel at the beginning of the year to US$54 by year-end. In Hong Kong’s stock market, the Hang Seng Index edged up by 86 points for the year, but the peak-to-trough difference exceeded 6,000 points during the period. Amidst such turbulent external conditions, the importance and value of maintaining the stability of the financial system—especially the monetary and banking systems—became even more apparent.

In January 2016, rumors of international hedge funds preparing to attack the renminbi and the Hong Kong dollar were rampant, causing widespread unease. The HKMA promptly delivered a clear and firm message to the market: we have absolute confidence and capability to defend the Linked Exchange Rate System and the stability of Hong Kong’s financial system, thereby stabilizing market confidence in a timely manner. Looking at the whole of 2016, the Hong Kong dollar remained close to the strong-side Convertibility Undertaking for extended periods. Due to the ample liquidity in the banking system, even after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates in December last year and March this year, there was no significant or immediate impact on Hong Kong dollar interest rates or the exchange rate.

Hong Kong’s banking system continued to develop steadily, with overall loans recording a moderate growth of 6.5% last year. Asset quality remained sound, with the non-performing loan ratio staying at a healthy level of 0.85%, well below the long-term average of about 2% since 2000. Both the capital adequacy ratio and liquidity ratio of the banking system remained well above statutory requirements. In the area of mortgage lending, after seven rounds of counter-cyclical measures, the average loan-to-value ratio for new residential mortgages fell from 64% in September 2009 to 51% at the end of 2016, while the average debt service ratio dropped from 41% in August 2010 to 34% at the end of 2016. These provide the necessary buffer for the banking system in the event of a market downturn. The HKMA will continue to closely monitor developments in the property market and adopt appropriate measures in response to cyclical changes to maintain the stability of the banking system.

Legislative work to further strengthen the stability of the banking system made encouraging progress last year. Two pieces of legislation—one to enhance the deposit protection scheme and another to address the "too big to fail" risk of financial institutions—were successfully passed before the end of the previous Legislative Council term. The former expedites the payout of deposit protection funds and simplifies the claims procedure, helping to strengthen depositors’ confidence in the banking system; the latter establishes a resolution mechanism for financial institutions, including banks, to guard against systemic financial risks in the event of their failure and to avoid, as far as possible, the use of public funds to bail them out. The HKMA established the Resolution Office on 1 April this year to implement and follow up on the requirements of the legislation.

The banking industry, long known as the "mother of all industries," is a vital source of savings, payment channels, and credit for the real economy and the daily lives of ordinary citizens. During the year, some SME representatives reported difficulties in obtaining financing. The HKMA immediately communicated with the banking sector, encouraging banks to continue providing funding support for the operations and development of SMEs as far as possible, while maintaining prudent risk management. Through the Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation, we also stepped up promotion of the Government’s "SME Financing Guarantee Scheme" to the business sector, and maintained close communication with the banking industry to dispel doubts, clarify misunderstandings, and streamline the claims procedures for bad debts, thereby increasing banks’ willingness to participate in the scheme. These multi-pronged efforts have yielded results: according to HKMA surveys, the overall credit lines for SMEs remained stable last year, with over 90% of enterprises having their credit lines maintained or even increased. At the same time, applications for the "SME Financing Guarantee Scheme" also rose significantly.

In recent years, the HKMA has vigorously promoted financial inclusion, recognizing that basic banking services are indispensable for business operations and daily life. Last year, upon learning that some overseas companies and start-ups were encountering difficulties in opening accounts in Hong Kong, we immediately followed up, liaising with various international chambers of commerce and business associations, and engaging in in-depth discussions with the banking sector to address the issues. In September last year, I issued a circular to all banks in Hong Kong, explaining how to interpret the HKMA’s "risk-based" regulatory principle for anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing, and how to apply this principle to account opening and ongoing customer due diligence. I emphasized that banks should not adopt a "one-size-fits-all" approach to requirements and procedures for all customers. Following our consultations with banks and the business community, the situation regarding account opening for businesses has improved, though there is still room for further progress. This remains one of our key priorities for this year.

Financial inclusion also involves the coverage of bank branch services. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has consistently encouraged banks to consider the basic banking service needs of the public, in addition to pursuing commercial profit. With the rapid advancement of financial technology, banks are offering increasingly diversified service channels. In addition to the growing popularity of online banking services, last year, several banks launched mobile banking vehicles and video teller machine services, providing more personalized and comprehensive banking services than traditional ATMs. Driven by our efforts, a number of banks are also planning to establish physical branches in remote areas to enhance services for local residents.

The development of a financial center is like sailing against the current; therefore, the HKMA has, over the years, continuously sought new opportunities and explored new frontiers for the development of Hong Kong’s financial industry. The year 2016 can be described as a fruitful one, with particular highlights in financial technology (Fintech) and infrastructure financing.

In terms of financial technology, Hong Kong’s retail payment services entered a new era in 2016. Last year, the HKMA issued 13 stored value payment instrument licenses, creating a favorable business environment for retail payment services through licensing and ongoing regulatory regimes. This was complemented by a series of public education campaigns, ensuring that while consumers enjoy the convenience brought by new technology, their rights and interests are also reasonably protected.

In addition, in March last year, the HKMA established the Fintech Facilitation Office as a platform to promote the development of fintech related to the banking industry. Within a few months, we launched several new initiatives, including the Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative, which established a new three-pronged platform for strengthening the banking system’s cybersecurity through risk assessment, information sharing, and talent development. We also collaborated with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) to conduct dedicated research on distributed ledger technology, exploring its applicability in Hong Kong’s banking sector, and established the Fintech Innovation Hub at ASTRI to provide technical support to the banking and fintech industries. The HKMA’s Banking Supervision Department also set up the Fintech Supervisory Sandbox, allowing banks to test new technologies within a smaller and controlled environment, thereby accelerating the development of new products and services. From September last year to March this year, six banks have used the sandbox to test a total of 14 new technology projects, some of which have already been launched in the market, bringing more fintech products to the public.

There is enormous global demand for infrastructure financing, especially since the launch of the Belt and Road Initiative, which has brought infrastructure financing into the international spotlight. As an international financial center in Asia, Hong Kong holds significant advantages in this field. In July last year, the HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO), creating a new and unique platform that brings together more than 60 world-class multilateral institutions, institutional investors, banks, insurance companies and other financial institutions, infrastructure project developers and operators, and various professional organizations to exchange information, share experiences, and seek cooperation opportunities on infrastructure investment and financing. Since its establishment, IFFO has organized more than ten major conferences, seminars, and workshops. The HKMA has also signed Memoranda of Understanding with the International Finance Corporation, the Global Infrastructure Hub, the China Development Bank, and The Export-Import Bank of China to jointly promote infrastructure investment and financing activities. Although the initiative is still in its early stages, it has laid a solid foundation for Hong Kong’s future as a center for infrastructure investment and financing.

Removing barriers and relaxing restrictions is the key to enhancing competitiveness. During the year, the HKMA actively participated in and supported the SAR Government’s amendment of tax ordinances to provide a favorable tax environment for enterprises conducting group treasury activities in Hong Kong. We also proactively engaged with multinational corporations to attract them to develop or expand their corporate treasury activities in Hong Kong, thereby further strengthening the functions of Hong Kong’s financial markets.

Last year, the offshore RMB market underwent a period of adjustment. Affected by market volatility and expectations regarding the RMB exchange rate, the scale of global offshore RMB liquidity pools generally contracted. Nevertheless, Hong Kong continued to lead the offshore RMB business, maintaining the world’s largest RMB liquidity pool, with RMB settlement through Hong Kong remaining at a high daily average of about RMB 860 billion. To further optimize liquidity arrangements in Hong Kong’s offshore RMB market, in October last year we increased the number of primary liquidity providers from seven to nine, and raised the total bilateral liquidity facility from RMB 14 billion to RMB 18 billion, ensuring orderly market operations even in times of tight liquidity. The launch of the Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect in December last year further energized Hong Kong’s RMB business. The HKMA is also working with Mainland authorities to study the Bond Connect scheme, which will further facilitate cross-border participation in the bond market and enhance the connectivity of bond market infrastructure.

Despite the various uncertainties in the global investment environment last year, thanks to a range of defensive measures implemented over time, the Exchange Fund recorded an investment income of HKD 68.1 billion last year. Since 1994, the Exchange Fund’s compound annual return rate has reached 4.8%, higher than the local inflation rate of 2.1% over the same period.

The Exchange Fund will continue to promote diversified investment, including further expanding asset classes and increasing investments in credit assets, inflation-hedging investment products, and emerging markets. As the flagship of diversified investment, the Long-Term Growth Portfolio invests in alternative assets such as private equity and real estate projects. Since its inception in 2009, the portfolio has consistently delivered solid results, with an average annual internal rate of return of approximately 12%. With the government's Future Fund partially allocated to this portfolio, we have accelerated our investment pace. By the end of last year, the asset size of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio was about HK$181.8 billion, with a total of approximately HK$133.8 billion approved but not yet drawn for investment. The Exchange Fund will continue to adhere to the investment strategy of 'capital preservation first, long-term appreciation,' seeking stable long-term returns while maintaining ample liquidity and reserve funds.

zh:
# 2016年摘要

# 經濟及金融環境

隨着環球經濟及貿易活動疲弱，香港經濟增長回軟。年內本港股市及住宅物業市場波動，置業負擔能力依然偏緊。

儘管環球市場風險及衝擊增加，香港銀行體系仍維持穩健。銀行資本及流動性狀況維持良好；資產質素輕微轉差，但仍處於健康水平。

# 貨幣穩定

儘管面對波動的外圍環境，港元匯率仍然保持穩定，反映聯繫匯率制度承受外來衝擊的能力。

貨幣市場繼續運作暢順，銀行同業流動資金充裕。於12月，繼美國聯邦儲備局決定上調聯邦基金利率目標範圍，香港基本利率上調25基點至1.00厘。

# 銀行體系穩定

金管局加強監管銀行的風險管治架構，以及信用、流動性與科技風險管理。金管局亦採取具體行動，促進普及金融和應對企業在香港開立及維持銀行帳戶遇到的困難。

監管政策方面，就本港實施國際監管及會計標準的準備工作取得重大進展，當中包括《金融機構（處置機制）條例》下的處置框架。

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

香港維持其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐和資產管理中心的地位。稅制獲進一步完善，營造更有利環境，吸引跨國公司在香港設立企業財資中心。

為發展香港成為基建融資中心與金融科技樞紐，金管局成立基建融資促進辦公室及金融科技促進辦公室。金管局順利開始實施儲值支付工具及零售支付系統的監管制度，並批出13個儲值支付工具牌照。

# 儲備管理

儘管投資環境困難，充斥黑天鵝事件，但有賴過去幾年所採取的一連串防禦措施，增強外匯基金的抗震能力，外匯基金錄得2%的整體投資回報。

金管局加快多元化投資的步伐，特別是長期增長組合的投資。

# 機構職能

金管局透過傳媒、公眾教育活動及其他各種渠道與社會和市場保持有效溝通，增進公眾對金管局政策及運作的了解。

金管局繼續加強機構管治，包括推動員工提升專業能力、嚴格控制財政及加強資訊科技保安，以應付推行新措施及日益繁重的工作所帶來的挑戰。

# 2016 Summary

# Economic and Financial Environment

With the global economy and trade activities remaining weak, Hong Kong’s economic growth softened. During the year, the local stock market and residential property market experienced volatility, and housing affordability remained tight.

Despite increased global market risks and shocks, Hong Kong’s banking system remained robust. Banks maintained strong capital and liquidity positions; asset quality saw a slight deterioration but remained at healthy levels.

# Monetary Stability

Despite a volatile external environment, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remained stable, reflecting the Linked Exchange Rate System’s resilience to external shocks.

The money market continued to function smoothly, and interbank liquidity remained ample. In December, following the US Federal Reserve’s decision to raise the target range for the Federal Funds Rate, Hong Kong’s Base Rate was raised by 25 basis points to 1.00%.

# Banking System Stability

The HKMA strengthened the risk governance framework of banks, as well as credit, liquidity, and technology risk management. The HKMA also took concrete actions to promote financial inclusion and address the difficulties faced by corporates in opening and maintaining bank accounts in Hong Kong.

On the regulatory front, significant progress was made in preparing for the implementation of international regulatory and accounting standards in Hong Kong, including the resolution framework under the Financial Institutions (Resolution) Ordinance.

# Hong Kong’s Status as an International Financial Centre

Hong Kong maintained its position as a global offshore RMB business hub and asset management centre. The tax regime was further refined to create a more favourable environment, attracting multinational corporations to establish corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong.

To develop Hong Kong as a centre for infrastructure financing and fintech, the HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office and the Fintech Facilitation Office. The HKMA successfully commenced the regulatory regime for stored value facilities and retail payment systems, and granted 13 stored value facility licenses.

# Reserve Management

Despite a challenging investment environment marked by black swan events, a series of defensive measures taken in recent years enhanced the Exchange Fund’s resilience, resulting in an overall investment return of 2%.

The HKMA accelerated the pace of diversified investments, particularly in the long-term growth portfolio.

# Institutional Functions

The HKMA maintained effective communication with the community and the market through the media, public education activities, and various other channels, enhancing public understanding of HKMA policies and operations.

The HKMA continued to strengthen institutional governance, including promoting staff professional competence, exercising strict fiscal control, and enhancing information technology security, in order to meet the challenges arising from the implementation of new measures and an increasingly heavy workload.

# 2016年大事紀要

# 1月

# 1月14日 

金管局公布，由2017年1月1日起香港適用的逆周期緩衝資本比率將上調至1.25%。

# 2月

# 2月5日

金管局與證券及期貨事務監察委員會（證監會）就場外衍生工具監管制度引入強制性結算及擴大強制性匯報的建議發表諮詢總結。

# 3月

#3月21日 

金管局成立金融科技促進辦公室，推動香港成為亞洲區金融科技樞紐。

# 5月

# 5月16日

金管局公布硬幣收集計劃延長服務多兩年至2018年9月止。

# 5月18日

金管局於2016年網絡安全高峰會上宣布推出「網絡防衛計劃」，進一步提升香港銀行業抵禦網絡攻擊的能力。

# 6月

# 6月1日至2日

金管局與中國銀行業監督管理委員會合辦香港銀行獨立非執行董事高級研修班。

# 6月3日

《2016年稅務（修訂）（第2號）條例》刊憲，容許企業在符合指明條件下扣除集團內部融資業務利息支出，並為香港的企業財資中心提供稅務優惠。

# 6月10日

《2016年證券及期貨（修訂）條例》刊憲，引入開放式基金型公司新結構，使香港的基金註冊平台更多元化。

# 6月20日

在政府債券計劃下發行第六批零售通脹掛鈎債券(iBond)。

# 6月30日

《金融機構（處置機制）條例》刊憲，為在香港設立跨界別金融機構處置機制提供法律基礎。

# 7月

# 7月4日

金管局分別與國際金融公司及全球基礎設施中心簽署《諒解備忘錄》，透過IFFO平台促進亞洲基建項目的投資及融資。

金管局成立基建融資促進辦公室(IFFO)，推動香港發展為基建融資樞紐。

# 7月5日

金管局與博鰲亞洲論壇在香港合辦以「金融促進實體經濟」為題的金融合作會議。

# 7月20日

廣東省（包括深圳）與香港之間的電子支票聯合結算啟動。

# 8月

# 8月12日

在政府債券計劃下發行首批銀色債券。

# 8月25日

金管局宣布根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）向5個儲值支付工具發行人批出首批儲值支付工具牌照。

# 9月

# 9月6日

金管局與財資市場公會在香港合辦「2016財資市場高峰會」。

金管局推出「金融科技監管沙盒」，讓銀行在全面推出金融科技及其他科技項目前可預先試行。

# 9月28日

金管局主持在德國法蘭克福舉辦的研討會，推廣香港在中國機遇中扮演的角色。

# 10月

# 10月24日至25日

金管局、英倫銀行與國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）在香港合辦「金融危機後貨幣、金融和審慎監管政策的互動」高層次研討會。

# 10月26日至28日

IFFO主辦題為「私營資金參與新興市場基建項目的投融資」的首個行政人員工作坊，並宣布再有13家機構加入成為IFFO合作夥伴，令其總數增至超過50個。

# 10月27日

金管局擴大人民幣一級流動性提供行計劃，將提供行數目由7家增至9家，並把計劃的總額度增至180億元人民幣。金管局人民幣流動資金安排使用情況的透明度亦增加。

# 11月

# 11月4日

金管局宣布根據《支付條例》批出第二批儲值支付工具牌照，令儲值支付工具持牌人總數增至13個。

# 11月8日

IFFO主辦高層研討會，由亞洲基礎設施投資銀行行長金立群先生析述該行的營運及基建項目。

# 11月11日

金管局舉辦「金融科技日」，並發表分布式分類帳技術的研究白皮書。

金管局與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作成立「金融科技創新中心」，以助構思創新意念及試驗嶄新的金融科技技術。

# 11月22日

財經事務及庫務局與金管局、證監會及保險業監督聯合發表《金融機構（處置機制）條例》下有關受保障安排建議規例的諮詢文件。

金管局與香港中國企業協會簽署《諒解備忘錄》，幫助更多中資企業在港設立企業財資中心。

# Major Events of 2016

# January

# January 14

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced that the countercyclical capital buffer ratio applicable in Hong Kong would be raised to 1.25% with effect from January 1, 2017.

# February

# February 5

The HKMA and the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) published the consultation conclusion on the proposed introduction of mandatory clearing and expansion of mandatory reporting under the regulatory regime for over-the-counter derivatives.

# March

# March 21

The HKMA established the Fintech Facilitation Office to promote Hong Kong as a fintech hub in Asia.

# May

# May 16

The HKMA announced the extension of the Coin Collection Scheme for another two years until September 2018.

# May 18

At the 2016 Cybersecurity Summit, the HKMA announced the launch of the Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative to further enhance the Hong Kong banking sector’s ability to withstand cyber attacks.

# June

# June 1–2

The HKMA and the China Banking Regulatory Commission jointly organized an advanced workshop for independent non-executive directors of Hong Kong banks.

# June 3

The Inland Revenue (Amendment) (No.2) Ordinance 2016 was gazetted, allowing enterprises to deduct interest expenses on intra-group financing business under specified conditions and providing tax concessions for corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong.

# June 10

The Securities and Futures (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 was gazetted, introducing a new open-ended fund company structure to further diversify Hong Kong’s fund registration platform.

# June 20

The sixth batch of retail inflation-linked bonds (iBond) was issued under the Government Bond Programme.

# June 30

The Financial Institutions (Resolution) Ordinance was gazetted, providing the legal foundation for establishing a cross-sectoral financial institution resolution mechanism in Hong Kong.

# July

# July 4

The HKMA signed Memoranda of Understanding with the International Finance Corporation and the Global Infrastructure Hub to promote investment and financing of Asian infrastructure projects through the IFFO platform.

The HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) to promote Hong Kong’s development as an infrastructure financing hub.

# July 5

The HKMA and the Boao Forum for Asia jointly organized a financial cooperation conference in Hong Kong themed "Finance Facilitating the Real Economy."

# July 20

Joint e-cheque clearing between Guangdong Province (including Shenzhen) and Hong Kong was launched.

# August

# August 12

The first batch of Silver Bonds was issued under the Government Bond Programme.

# August 25

The HKMA announced the issuance of the first batch of stored value facility licenses to five issuers under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the Payment Ordinance).

# September

# September 6

The HKMA and the Treasury Markets Association jointly organized the "2016 Treasury Markets Summit" in Hong Kong.

The HKMA launched the Fintech Regulatory Sandbox, allowing banks to conduct pilot trials of fintech and other technology initiatives before full launch.

# September 28

The HKMA hosted a seminar in Frankfurt, Germany, to promote Hong Kong’s role in China opportunities.

# October

# October 24–25

The HKMA, Bank of England, and International Monetary Fund (IMF) jointly organized a high-level seminar in Hong Kong on "Interaction of Monetary, Financial and Prudential Regulatory Policies after the Financial Crisis."

# October 26–28

IFFO hosted its first executive workshop on "Mobilizing Private Capital for Infrastructure Investment and Financing in Emerging Markets," and announced that 13 more institutions had joined as IFFO partners, bringing the total to over 50.

# October 27

The HKMA expanded the RMB Primary Liquidity Provider Scheme, increasing the number of provider banks from seven to nine and raising the total quota to RMB 18 billion. Transparency regarding the use of the HKMA’s RMB liquidity arrangements was also enhanced.

# November

# November 4

The HKMA announced the issuance of the second batch of stored value facility licenses under the Payment Ordinance, bringing the total number of licensees to 13.

# November 8

IFFO hosted a high-level seminar, with Mr. Jin Liqun, President of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, sharing insights on the bank’s operations and infrastructure projects.

# November 11

The HKMA held "Fintech Day" and published a research white paper on distributed ledger technology.

The HKMA and the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) jointly established the Fintech Innovation Centre to foster innovative ideas and pilot new fintech technologies.

# November 22

The Financial Services and the Treasury Bureau, together with the HKMA, SFC, and Insurance Authority, jointly published a consultation paper on the proposed regulations for protected arrangements under the Financial Institutions (Resolution) Ordinance.

The HKMA signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Hong Kong Chinese Enterprises Association to assist more Mainland Chinese enterprises in establishing corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong.

zh:
# 經濟及金融環境

隨着環球經濟及貿易活動疲弱，香港經濟增長在2016年回軟。面對外圍環境不明朗因素加劇，預期2017年經濟增長仍然溫和。

# 經濟回顧

# 概覽

香港經濟增長在2016年放緩，實質本地生產總值增長由2015年的2.4%降至1.9%（表1）。淨出口是主要拖累，當中訪港旅遊業疲弱令服務輸出受壓（圖1）。本地需求動力亦放緩，但繼續為整體經濟增長提供主要支持。勞工市場大致保持穩定，失業率維持於3.3至3.4%的低位。由於本地成本及外部價格壓力減退，消費物價通脹進一步放緩。面對波動的外圍環境及多變的市場氣氛，資產市場增添起伏。鑑於住宅物業市場再度暢旺，政府於11月實施新印花稅措施。

儘管外圍環境波動及美元利率上升，本港外匯及貨幣市場繼續運作暢順。港元現貨匯率於1月份略為轉弱後一直在7.75附近水平徘徊。年內兌換保證並無被觸發，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券合計幾乎維持不變，約為1.2萬億港元。繼美國於12月中加息後，金管局基本利率由0.75厘上調至1厘。香港銀行同業拆息及較長期債券收益率維持在相對較低水平，但在接近年底時稍升，部分反映美元相應拆息及收益率的走勢。整體銀行貸款增長在2016年加快至6.5%。雖然整體貸款質素略為轉差，但特定分類貸款比率仍然維持在極低水平。

圖 1 組成部分對實質本地生產總值增長的貢獻
資料來源：政府統計處。

表 1 按開支項目計的實質本地生產總值增長（比對上期）

註：本地固定資本形成總額經季節因素調整的按季增減幅度不詳。
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 本地需求

本地需求的增長力度在2016年略為減弱。儘管穩定的就業及收入狀況繼續為私人消費帶來支持，但其增速仍降至1.6%，部分反映經濟不明朗因素加劇。政府消費增長亦略為減慢至3.3%。本地固定資本形成總額繼續按季大幅上落（圖2），累計全年收縮0.5%。私營部門機器及設備購置成為主要拖累，在營商前景欠佳下連續第3年收縮，而樓宇及建造活動則因住屋動工項目增加而轉殷。

圖 2 本地需求
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 外部需求

香港出口在接近2016年底時有回穩跡象，但綜合全年表現仍然乏力（圖3）。貨品出口較2015年的低基數上升1.7%。香港對先進經濟體的出口仍然呆滯；但在區內貿易流動轉趨穩定下，香港對中國內地、印度、韓國、新加坡及台灣的出口則較2015年好轉。

部分反映零售銷售在近年急速增長後轉趨正常化，香港服務輸出在2016年顯著收縮3.1%。貨品進口在2015年收縮後於2016年收復部分失地，服務輸入則部分受惠於本地居民外遊意欲而持續增長。2016年整體貿易順差收窄，拖累本地經濟增長。

圖 3 貨品出口及服務輸出
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 通脹

通脹壓力在2016年仍然受控。剔除政府一次性紓緩措施的影響後，基本通脹率由2015年的2.5%下降至2016年的2.3%（圖4）。在早前新訂私人住宅租金下調所帶來的傳遞效應下，綜合消費物價指數中的租金組成項目通脹回落。受惠於全球商品價格偏軟及港元強勢，進口價格通脹受到遏抑。另一方面，在勞工成本穩定增長及租金成本壓力（尤其零售範疇）有所紓緩下，本地成本壓力保持溫和。

圖 4 基本消費物價通脹
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 勞工市場

勞工市場在2016年大致保持穩定，勞工供求升幅相若。按行業分析，旅遊相關行業的勞工市場狀況轉差，其他行業則大致平穩。整體而言，經季節因素調整失業率由2015年的3.3%稍升至3.4%（圖5）。在勞工市場穩定下，名義工資在首3季上升3.8%，而2015年的升幅為4.6%。首3季實質工資亦上升0.9%，而2015年的升幅為1.5%。

圖 5 勞工市場狀況
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 股市

香港股市在2016年大幅上落。受到人民幣貶值壓力及內地股市波動所影響，恒生指數於2月份跌至3年來的低位（圖6）。本港股市在3月份跟隨美國及其他主要股市顯著造好而回升。儘管英國脫歐公投觸發市場波動，但在外界預期美國聯邦儲備局會放緩加息步伐及其他主要央行推行貨幣寬鬆政策下，市場氣氛迅速改善。恒生指數於9月份升至24,100點的一年高位。然而，受到美國總統選舉結果及預計美國會加快加息步伐所影響，本港股市在第4季再度受壓。整體而言，恒生指數於2016年微升0.4%，在2015年則下跌7.2%。平均每日成交額由上年的1,056億港元降至669億港元，而本港股市集資總額亦由上年的11,156億港元減少至4,901億港元。

圖 6 資產價格
資料來源：差餉物業估價署及香港交易及結算所有限公司。

# 物業市場

住宅物業市場在2016年略為波動。物業成交量於第1季錄得歷史新低後，在其後數月有所回升，但在11月推出新印花稅措施後再度下挫。整體而言，成交量在2016年稍跌至54,701宗。另一方面，樓價自第2季起上升並超越2015年9月的高位，2016年的累計升幅為7.8%（圖6）。置業負擔能力依然偏緊，樓價與收入比率為15.9，超越1997年的歷史高位；而收入槓桿比率為72.0%，遠高於長期平均水平。2 由於銀行推出具競爭力的按揭計劃，按揭利率稍為回落，於接近年底時則跟隨香港銀行同業拆息上升而略為回升。工商物業市場方面，全年交投大致保持穩定。由於非住宅物業價格較2015年高位回落，相應租金收益率較上年微升，但仍處於低位。

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

預期2017年實質本地生產總值增長將保持溫和。政府預測經濟增長幅度介乎2至3%之間，私營機構分析員預測增幅平均為2.0%。外圍方面，隨着環球宏觀經濟及金融環境變得不明朗，全球經濟及貿易增長或會保持溫和；再加上港元實質有效匯率因美元強勢而上升，將會抑制香港的出口表現。本地方面，雖然穩定的就業及收入狀況會支持消費，但受利率上升所拖累，預期私人消費會溫和增長。受惠於住屋供應增加及多個基建項目展開，樓宇及建造活動應會穩步增長，但營商氣氛疲弱及利率趨升將影響商界資本投資。

# 通脹及勞工市場

預計2017年通脹壓力仍然溫和。一方面環球商品價格上漲及中國內地通脹趨升或會令進口價格上升，另一方面港元轉強卻可能會令上述壓力受到遏抑。在溫和的經濟動力下，本地成本壓力仍可受控，但由於新訂住宅租金於2017年初上升，綜合消費物價指數中的租金組成項目通脹可能會稍升。市場共識預測2017年整體通脹率為1.9%，政府預期基本通脹率為2.0%。雖然不明朗因素加劇或會影響招聘意欲，私營機構分析員預計2017年失業率會維持於3.4%。

# 不明朗因素及風險

2017年經濟前景會受制於眾多不明朗因素，當中來自外圍環境的影響尤甚。美國新一屆政府政策的不確定性，將令環球經濟前景變得不明朗，當中可能出現的保護主義政策亦會對全球貿易帶來阻力。英國脫歐進程及歐洲幾個主要國家舉行大選，亦可能導致資產市場波動，並影響港元資金流向。此外，美國利率正常化將會令本地貨幣狀況收緊，並對實質經濟及資產價格構成下調壓力；當中樓市繼續偏緊，市場前景仍然很不明朗。短期而言，按揭息率仍然偏低、就業及收入狀況穩定，以及地產發展商加推優惠（例如折扣及現金回贈）令累積的購買力獲得釋放，均可為住宅需求帶來支持。另一方面，新印花稅措施、美國可能加快加息步伐及房屋供應穩步增長，則可能繼續為樓市帶來阻力。

# 銀行體系表現

儘管本港經濟面對阻力，加上國際政治事件出乎意料的結果令市場波動加劇，香港銀行體系在2016年仍然穩健。認可機構的資本及流動性狀況維持良好，資產質素輕微轉差，但仍處於健康水平。

# 利率走勢

隨着美國利率上升，香港銀行同業拆息在11月及12月顯著上升。反映零售銀行港元資金成本的綜合利率則輕微上升（圖7）。

圖 7 香港銀行同業拆息、綜合利率及最優惠貸款利率

註：
1. 香港銀行同業拆息（每月平均數）由香港銀行公會公布。
2. 最優惠貸款利率（每月平均數）是參考香港上海滙豐銀行有限公司所報利率。

# 盈利走勢

零售銀行在2016年的盈利略為改善，其香港業務的整體除稅前經營溢利增長8.7%。增長主要是由外匯及衍生工具業務收入（+39.7%）、附屬公司派發的股息收入（+123.5%）及淨利息收入（+2.8%）所帶動，不過部份增長被費用及佣金收入減少(-11.3%)所抵銷。零售銀行除稅後溢利錄得44.4%的升幅，增長主要來自非經常項目。零售銀行除稅後平均資產回報率亦相應由2015 年的 1.04% 上升至 1.44%（圖 8）。

圖8 零售銀行的表現

2016年零售銀行淨息差為1.32%，與2015年的水平相同（圖9）。雖然零售銀行繼續將剩餘資金配置於息率較低而流動性較高的金融投資，但利息收益的減少被利息成本下降所抵銷。

圖9 零售銀行淨息差

零售銀行非利息收入佔總經營收入的比例為44.3%，大致維持穩定。雖然費用與佣金收入下跌11.3%，但股息收入及外匯與衍生工具業務收入分別上升123.5%及39.7%。

# Economic and Financial Environment

With the global economy and trade activities remaining weak, Hong Kong's economic growth softened in 2016. Facing heightened external uncertainties, economic growth in 2017 is expected to remain moderate.

# Economic Review

# Overview

Hong Kong's economic growth slowed in 2016, with real GDP growth declining from 2.4% in 2015 to 1.9% (Table 1). Net exports were the main drag, with the weak inbound tourism sector putting pressure on service exports (Chart 1). Domestic demand momentum also weakened, but continued to provide the main support for overall economic growth. The labour market remained broadly stable, with the unemployment rate staying at a low level of 3.3% to 3.4%. As both local cost and external price pressures eased, consumer price inflation further moderated. Amid a volatile external environment and fluctuating market sentiment, asset markets experienced increased volatility. Given the renewed buoyancy in the residential property market, the government implemented new stamp duty measures in November.

Despite external volatility and rising US interest rates, Hong Kong's foreign exchange and money markets continued to function smoothly. After a slight weakening in January, the HKD spot exchange rate hovered around 7.75. The convertibility undertaking was not triggered during the year, and the aggregate balance together with outstanding Exchange Fund Bills and Notes remained virtually unchanged at around HK$1.2 trillion. Following the US interest rate hike in mid-December, the HKMA Base Rate was raised from 0.75% to 1%. HIBOR and longer-term bond yields remained at relatively low levels, but edged up towards the end of the year, partly reflecting movements in corresponding US dollar rates and yields. Overall bank lending growth accelerated to 6.5% in 2016. Although overall loan quality slightly deteriorated, the classified loan ratio remained at an extremely low level.

Chart 1 Contribution of Components to Real GDP Growth
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

Table 1 Real GDP Growth by Expenditure Component (Quarter-on-Quarter Comparison)

Note: Seasonally adjusted quarter-on-quarter changes in gross domestic fixed capital formation are not available.
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Domestic Demand

The growth momentum of domestic demand slightly weakened in 2016. Despite stable employment and income conditions continuing to provide support for private consumption, its growth rate still fell to 1.6%, partly reflecting increased economic uncertainties. Government consumption growth also slowed slightly to 3.3%. Gross domestic fixed capital formation continued to fluctuate significantly on a quarterly basis (Chart 2), contracting by 0.5% for the year as a whole. Private sector machinery and equipment investment was the main drag, shrinking for the third consecutive year amid a subdued business outlook, while building and construction activity picked up due to increased housing starts.

Chart 2 Domestic Demand
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# External Demand

Hong Kong's exports showed signs of stabilisation towards the end of 2016, but overall annual performance remained sluggish (Chart 3). Goods exports rose 1.7% from the low base in 2015. Exports to advanced economies remained sluggish; however, with intra-regional trade flows stabilising, exports to Mainland China, India, South Korea, Singapore, and Taiwan improved compared to 2015.

Partly reflecting a normalisation after rapid growth in recent years, Hong Kong's service exports contracted significantly by 3.1% in 2016. After contracting in 2015, goods imports regained some lost ground in 2016, while service imports continued to grow, partly benefiting from increased outbound travel by local residents. The overall trade surplus narrowed in 2016, weighing on Hong Kong's economic growth.

Chart 3 Goods Exports and Service Exports
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Inflation

Inflationary pressures remained contained in 2016. Excluding the effects of the government's one-off relief measures, the underlying inflation rate fell from 2.5% in 2015 to 2.3% in 2016 (Chart 4). Due to the lagged effect of earlier declines in new private residential rents, inflation in the rental component of the Composite Consumer Price Index moderated. Benefiting from subdued global commodity prices and a strong Hong Kong dollar, import price inflation was contained. On the other hand, with stable growth in labour costs and some easing of rental cost pressures (especially in the retail sector), local cost pressures remained moderate.

Chart 4 Underlying Consumer Price Inflation
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Labour Market

The labour market remained broadly stable in 2016, with labour supply and demand rising at similar rates. By industry, labour market conditions in tourism-related sectors deteriorated, while other sectors remained broadly stable. Overall, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate edged up from 3.3% in 2015 to 3.4% (Chart 5). With a stable labour market, nominal wages rose by 3.8% in the first three quarters, compared with a 4.6% increase in 2015. Real wages also rose by 0.9% in the first three quarters, compared with a 1.5% increase in 2015.

Chart 5 Labour Market Conditions
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Stock Market

Hong Kong's stock market experienced significant fluctuations in 2016. Affected by depreciation pressure on the renminbi and volatility in Mainland China's stock market, the Hang Seng Index fell to a three-year low in February (Chart 6). The local stock market rebounded in March, following notable improvements in the US and other major stock markets. Although the Brexit referendum triggered market volatility, market sentiment quickly improved as expectations grew that the US Federal Reserve would slow the pace of interest rate hikes and other major central banks would implement monetary easing policies. The Hang Seng Index climbed to a one-year high of 24,100 points in September. However, due to the outcome of the US presidential election and expectations of a faster pace of US interest rate hikes, the local stock market came under renewed pressure in the fourth quarter. Overall, the Hang Seng Index edged up by 0.4% in 2016, compared to a 7.2% decline in 2015. The average daily turnover fell from HK$105.6 billion in the previous year to HK$66.9 billion, while total funds raised in the local stock market also decreased from HK$1,115.6 billion to HK$490.1 billion.

Chart 6 Asset Prices
Source: Rating and Valuation Department and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited.

# Property Market

The residential property market was somewhat volatile in 2016. After transaction volume hit a historic low in the first quarter, it rebounded in the following months, but fell again after the introduction of new stamp duty measures in November. Overall, transaction volume edged down slightly to 54,701 cases in 2016. On the other hand, housing prices began to rise from the second quarter, surpassing the September 2015 peak, with a cumulative increase of 7.8% for 2016 (Chart 6). Housing affordability remained tight, with the price-to-income ratio at 15.9, exceeding the historical high in 1997; the income gearing ratio stood at 72.0%, well above the long-term average.2 Due to banks offering competitive mortgage schemes, mortgage rates fell slightly, but edged up towards the end of the year in line with the rise in HIBOR. As for the commercial property market, overall transaction activity remained broadly stable throughout the year. As non-residential property prices retreated from the 2015 peak, corresponding rental yields rose slightly compared to the previous year, but remained at low levels.

# Economic Outlook

# Economic Environment

Real GDP growth in 2017 is expected to remain moderate. The government forecasts economic growth in the range of 2 to 3%, while private sector analysts project an average increase of 2.0%. Externally, with the global macroeconomic and financial environment becoming more uncertain, global economic and trade growth may remain moderate; in addition, the real effective exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar is expected to rise due to the strong US dollar, which will dampen Hong Kong's export performance. Domestically, while stable employment and income conditions will support consumption, private consumption is expected to grow moderately, weighed down by rising interest rates. Benefiting from increased housing supply and the commencement of several infrastructure projects, building and construction activity should grow steadily, but weak business sentiment and rising interest rates will affect business capital investment.

# Inflation and Labour Market

Inflationary pressure is expected to remain moderate in 2017. On the one hand, rising global commodity prices and higher inflation in Mainland China may push up import prices; on the other hand, a stronger Hong Kong dollar may help contain these pressures. With moderate economic momentum, local cost pressures should remain manageable, but as new residential rents rose at the beginning of 2017, inflation in the rental component of the Composite Consumer Price Index may edge up. Market consensus forecasts an overall inflation rate of 1.9% for 2017, while the government expects the underlying inflation rate to be 2.0%. Although heightened uncertainties may affect hiring intentions, private sector analysts expect the unemployment rate to remain at 3.4% in 2017.

# Uncertainties and Risks

The economic outlook for 2017 will be subject to numerous uncertainties, particularly those arising from the external environment. The uncertainty surrounding the policies of the new US administration will cloud the global economic outlook, and possible protectionist policies may pose resistance to global trade. The Brexit process and elections in several major European countries may also lead to volatility in asset markets and affect capital flows in the Hong Kong dollar. In addition, the normalization of US interest rates will tighten local monetary conditions and exert downward pressure on the real economy and asset prices; the property market remains tight, and the market outlook is still highly uncertain. In the short term, mortgage rates remain low, stable employment and income conditions, and additional incentives offered by property developers (such as discounts and cash rebates) that have released pent-up purchasing power, all provide support for residential demand. On the other hand, new stamp duty measures, a possible acceleration in US interest rate hikes, and steady growth in housing supply may continue to pose resistance to the property market.

# Banking Sector Performance

Despite headwinds facing the local economy and increased market volatility due to unexpected international political events, Hong Kong's banking sector remained robust in 2016. The capital and liquidity position of authorized institutions remained sound, and asset quality deteriorated slightly but stayed at healthy levels.

# Interest Rate Trends

With US interest rates rising, HIBOR in Hong Kong rose significantly in November and December. The composite interest rate, reflecting the funding cost of retail banks in Hong Kong dollars, also edged up slightly (Chart 7).

Chart 7 HIBOR, Composite Interest Rate, and Prime Lending Rate in Hong Kong

Note:
1. The Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate (monthly average) is published by the Hong Kong Association of Banks.
2. The Prime Lending Rate (monthly average) is based on the rate quoted by The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited.

# Profitability Trends

Retail banks saw a slight improvement in profitability in 2016, with pre-tax operating profit from their Hong Kong operations increasing by 8.7%. The growth was mainly driven by income from foreign exchange and derivatives business (+39.7%), dividend income from subsidiaries (+123.5%), and net interest income (+2.8%). However, part of the increase was offset by a decrease in fee and commission income (-11.3%). Retail banks recorded a 44.4% increase in post-tax profit, mainly attributable to non-recurring items. The post-tax average return on assets for retail banks also rose from 1.04% in 2015 to 1.44% (see Chart 8).

Chart 8 Performance of Retail Banks

In 2016, the net interest margin of retail banks was 1.32%, unchanged from the 2015 level (see Chart 9). Although retail banks continued to allocate surplus funds to financial investments with lower yields but higher liquidity, the reduction in interest income was offset by a decrease in interest expense.

Chart 9 Net Interest Margin of Retail Banks

Non-interest income accounted for 44.3% of total operating income for retail banks, remaining broadly stable. While fee and commission income declined by 11.3%, dividend income and income from foreign exchange and derivatives business increased by 123.5% and 39.7%, respectively.

zh:
# 貨幣穩定

儘管外圍環境波動及美元息率上升，港元匯率在2016年仍然保持穩定。香港貨幣市場亦繼續運作暢順，銀行同業流動資金充裕。聯繫匯率制度繼續展現高度承受衝擊的能力，是香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石。

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：
- 負債證明書（為3間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣
- 銀行在金管局所持結算戶口的結餘總額（即總結餘）
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

表1 貨幣基礎

金管局透過自動利率調節機制及履行兌換保證的堅決承諾來維持港元匯率的穩定。若市場對港元的需求大過供應，令市場匯率轉強至7.75港元兌1美元的強方兌換保證匯率，金管局會向銀行沽出港元、買入美元，使總結餘增加及港元利率下跌，從而令港元匯率從強方兌換保證匯率水平回復至7.75到7.85的兌換範圍內。相反，若港元供過於求，令市場匯率轉弱至7.85港元兌1美元的弱方兌換保證匯率，金管局會向銀行買入港元，使總結餘減少及推高港元利率，港元匯率隨之由弱方兌換保證匯率水平回復至兌換範圍內。

# 2016年回顧

# 匯率穩定

港元匯率在2016年首兩個月略有波動後，於年內餘下時間一直窄幅徘徊。港元在2016年初兌美元顯著轉弱，由1月4日的7.7510降至1月20日的7.8196（圖1）。港元匯率轉弱符合聯繫匯率制度的正常運作，反映美國在2015年12月加息後港元與美元的負息差擴濶。此外，其他市場相關因素，包括香港股市出現拋售、內地及香港經濟前景不及以前樂觀、人民幣匯率波動增加，以及亞洲貨幣普遍疲弱，均導致港元需求減弱。受到市場氣氛改善支持，港元匯率在2月略為轉強，並自3月起一直在7.753至7.776之間窄幅徘徊，即使英國脫歐公投及美國總統選舉引發市場波動亦未受影響。由於市場預期美國會在夏季加息，港元匯率於5月出現短暫的轉弱壓力。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2016年一直正常運作。

圖 1 2016年市場匯率

由於兌換保證沒有被觸發，因此總結餘及未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額在2016年沒有明顯變動，大致維持在12,222億港元左右（圖2）。年內金管局增發總值1,320億港元的外匯基金票據，以滿足銀行在流動性管理方面的龐大需求，令總結餘相應減少至2016年底的2,596億港元。增發外匯基金票據符合貨幣發行局制度的原則，這是由於增發外匯基金票據只屬貨幣基礎組成部分之間的轉移，即由總結餘移至未償還外匯基金票據及債券，貨幣基礎仍然由外匯儲備提供十足支持。

圖 2 2016年總結餘及未償還外匯基金票據及債券

# 貨幣市場

香港銀行同業拆息在2016年大部分時間維持在較低水平（圖3）。香港銀行同業拆息在1、2月期間因金融市場波動加劇而面對一些上升壓力，但在3月隨着金融環境回復平靜而轉趨穩定。於第2及第3季，儘管市場關注英國脫歐公投結果以及美國貨幣市場基金改革，香港銀行同業拆息仍大致保持穩定。部分受到年底資金需求影響，以及港元拆息追回美元拆息的升幅，香港銀行同業拆息在第4季錄得較大升幅。儘管如此，短期銀行同業拆息在2016年大致維持在低於基本利率的水平。

因應美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍於12月14日（美國時間）由0.25至0.50厘上調至0.50至0.75厘，基本利率於12月15日由0.75厘上調至1.00厘。基本利率的調整是按照於2009年3月26日宣布的經修訂計算公式作出。按照該公式，基本利率定於美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍下限加50基點的水平，或隔夜與1個月香港銀行同業拆息的5天移動平均數的平均值水平，兩者以較高者為準。

圖 3 2016年香港銀行同業拆息

港元遠期匯率點子在1月出現大幅溢價，大致跟隨港元與美元息差的走勢，以及部分反映投資者為其港股組合作出外匯對沖的需求（圖4）。遠期匯率溢價在2月開始收窄。隨着市況轉趨穩定，港元遠期匯率點子在3至11月期間大致保持穩定，其後在12月因港元與美元息差收窄而再度上升。整體而言，香港貨幣市場運作暢順，銀行同業流動資金充裕。貼現窗借貸在2016年並不活躍，僅涉及53億港元。

# 聯繫匯率制度

儘管經歷多次區內以至全球金融危機，聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）過去數十年來一直是香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石。2016年初市場波動加劇，再度引起有關港元轉弱及情況有如亞洲金融危機時期的評論。為增進各界對聯匯制度的認識，金管局向公眾闡釋聯匯制度的技術細節，並指出香港金融體系有能力抵禦衝擊。政府亦重申堅決維持聯匯制度。外匯及貨幣市場穩定，進一步鞏固公眾對政府維持聯匯制度的決心以及港元作為支付及保值貨幣的信心。國際貨幣基金組織在與香港進行年度第四條磋商時，明確表示聯匯制度是最適合香港的貨幣制度，指出香港靈活的經濟結構、充裕的財政及儲備緩衝、以及穩健有效的金融監管是聯匯制度的後盾。

圖 4 2016年美元兌港元遠期匯率點子

鑑於穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用，金管局繼續密切監察銀行的信用、流動性及利率風險管理以及壓力測試結果，並加強對銀行個人、企業及內地相關貸款的監管，以確保銀行體系具備應付衝擊的能力。面對美國貨幣政策正常化，香港銀行同業拆息開始上升，金管局提醒市民保持警覺，並作好準備以應付可能出現的市場波動及風險。

為提高貨幣發行局帳目的透明度，自1998年10月起，外匯基金已有部分資產被指定用作支持貨幣基礎。支持比率（即支持資產相對貨幣基礎的比率）於2016年在106.3至107.5%之間的窄幅上落，並無觸及上限或下限。該比率於2016年12月31日為106.7%（圖5）。在聯匯制度下，雖然已指定某些外匯基金資產作為支持組合，但外匯基金的全部資產均可用作支持港元匯率。外匯基金的龐大財政資源，能在面對突如其來的衝擊時為香港貨幣及金融穩定提供強力後盾。

圖5 2016年支持比率每日變動

# 研究工作

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的貨幣發行委員會負責監察和探討與香港貨幣及金融穩定有關的課題。在2016年，貨幣發行委員會探討的課題包括香港與中國內地及美國經濟增長同步性、港元貨幣外部需求及香港的金融狀況指數。貨幣發行委員會會議紀錄及金管局向其呈交的貨幣發行局制度運作報告，均載於金管局網站。

香港金融研究中心繼續支持貨幣政策、銀行業及金融範疇的研究工作。在2016年，研究中心合共邀請18位學者到訪，並發表20份工作論文。

年內研究中心舉辦6項國際會議及研討會，主要包括：
- 於1月舉辦「第7屆中國經濟年度國際研討會」，主題為「中國對全球經濟的影響日益加深」，其間發表8份涵蓋廣泛議題的研究論文，包括中國增長再平衡及增長潛力、來自中國的經濟外溢效應、人民幣對全球及區內的影響，以及人民幣市場之間的利差交易走勢及資訊流動。
- 於3月與香港科技大學及慶應大學合辦「科技大學與慶應大學及研究中心匯率及宏觀經濟研討會」，內容涵蓋多個不同經濟議題，包括全球經濟失衡、匯率動態變化、資本管制及貨幣政策。
- 於8月與香港城市大學合辦「房地產與金融穩定研討會」，會上發表的論文內容涵蓋年齡、人口與住屋需求；大額投資者對資產質素的影響；香港房屋價格動態變動；住屋市場負擔能力；按揭規例對家庭生命周期置業決定的影響，以及中國內地的住宅物業市場。
- 於10月與金管局及國際結算銀行合辦有關亞太區經濟體系的研討會，主題為「在動盪不穩的全球環境下區內經濟體系的抗震能力」。研討會吸引多間央行的高層、主要學者及來自國際組織與私人機構的專家出席，就亞太區經濟體系最迫切的事項進行互動式圓桌討論，交流意見。探討的議題涵蓋廣泛，包括亞洲的金融失衡狀況、資金流、內地經濟放緩對區內其他地方的外溢效應，以及亞洲潛在增長受到的影響及前景。

研究中心亦於8月舉辦「第14屆年度夏季研討會」，並於9月舉辦「第14屆中國內地經濟研討會」，探討內地銀行的資產質素及金融穩定事項。上述會議及研討會吸引學術界、金融服務界及各地央行代表參加。研究中心亦於年內舉辦21場公開小型研討會，探討廣泛的經濟、貨幣及金融議題。

# 紙幣及硬幣

截至2016年底，流通銀行紙幣（指發鈔銀行發行的紙幣）總值4,078億港元，較上年增加13.2%（圖6、7及8）。政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣總值118億港元，較上年增加5.3%（圖9及10）。在政府發行的紙幣及硬幣中，10港元流通紙幣總值44億港元，當中塑質鈔票佔86%。

# Monetary Stability

Despite volatility in the external environment and rising US dollar interest rates, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remained stable in 2016. The Hong Kong money market also continued to function smoothly, with ample interbank liquidity. The Linked Exchange Rate System continued to demonstrate a high degree of resilience to shocks, serving as the cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability.

# Target

The primary objective of Hong Kong’s monetary policy is to maintain monetary stability, that is, to ensure the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate, keeping the HKD/USD rate within the range of 7.75 to 7.85 Hong Kong dollars per US dollar in the foreign exchange market. This monetary regime mainly adopts the Currency Board System, which requires that the US dollar reserves held by the Exchange Fund provide at least 100% backing for the monetary base; any change in the monetary base must be matched by a corresponding change in US dollar reserves, maintaining a 100% alignment with changes in the monetary base.

The monetary base (Table 1) includes:
- Certificates of Indebtedness (which provide full backing for banknotes issued by the three note-issuing banks)
- Government-issued circulating banknotes and coins
- The aggregate balance of clearing accounts maintained by banks with the HKMA (i.e., the aggregate balance)
- Exchange Fund Bills and Notes issued by the HKMA on behalf of the government.

Table 1 Monetary Base

The HKMA maintains the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate through the Automatic Interest Rate Adjustment Mechanism and a firm commitment to the Convertibility Undertaking. If demand for the Hong Kong dollar exceeds supply, causing the market exchange rate to strengthen to the strong-side Convertibility Undertaking rate of 7.75 HKD per USD, the HKMA will sell Hong Kong dollars and buy US dollars from banks, increasing the aggregate balance and lowering Hong Kong dollar interest rates, thereby bringing the exchange rate back within the 7.75 to 7.85 range. Conversely, if the supply of Hong Kong dollars exceeds demand, causing the market exchange rate to weaken to the weak-side Convertibility Undertaking rate of 7.85 HKD per USD, the HKMA will buy Hong Kong dollars from banks, reducing the aggregate balance and pushing up Hong Kong dollar interest rates, thus returning the exchange rate to within the target range.

# Review of 2016

# Exchange Rate Stability

After some mild fluctuations in the first two months of 2016, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remained within a narrow range for the rest of the year. At the beginning of 2016, the Hong Kong dollar weakened significantly against the US dollar, falling from 7.7510 on January 4 to 7.8196 on January 20 (Chart 1). The weakening of the Hong Kong dollar was consistent with the normal operation of the Linked Exchange Rate System, reflecting the widening negative interest rate differential between the Hong Kong dollar and the US dollar following the US interest rate hike in December 2015. In addition, other market-related factors—including a sell-off in the Hong Kong stock market, less optimistic economic prospects for Mainland China and Hong Kong, increased volatility in the renminbi exchange rate, and general weakness in Asian currencies—also contributed to reduced demand for the Hong Kong dollar. Supported by improved market sentiment, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate strengthened slightly in February and, from March onwards, remained within a narrow range of 7.753 to 7.776, unaffected even by market volatility triggered by the Brexit referendum and the US presidential election. Due to market expectations of a US interest rate hike in the summer, the Hong Kong dollar experienced brief weakening pressure in May. Overall, the Hong Kong foreign exchange market operated normally throughout 2016.

Chart 1 2016 Market Exchange Rate

As the Convertibility Undertaking was not triggered, there were no significant changes in the aggregate balance and the outstanding amount of Exchange Fund Bills and Notes in 2016, which remained at around HKD 1,222.2 billion (Chart 2). During the year, the HKMA issued an additional HKD 132 billion in Exchange Fund Bills to meet strong demand from banks for liquidity management, resulting in a corresponding decrease in the aggregate balance to HKD 259.6 billion at the end of 2016. The issuance of additional Exchange Fund Bills is consistent with the principles of the Currency Board System, as it merely represents a transfer between components of the monetary base—from the aggregate balance to outstanding Exchange Fund Bills and Notes—while the monetary base continues to be fully backed by foreign exchange reserves.

Chart 2 2016 Aggregate Balance and Outstanding Exchange Fund Bills and Notes

# Money Market

Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rates (HIBOR) remained at relatively low levels for most of 2016 (Chart 3). HIBOR faced some upward pressure in January and February due to increased financial market volatility, but stabilized in March as financial conditions calmed. In the second and third quarters, despite market concerns over the outcome of the Brexit referendum and US money market fund reform, HIBOR remained generally stable. Partly due to year-end funding demand and the catch-up of Hong Kong dollar interbank rates with US dollar rates, HIBOR recorded a more significant increase in the fourth quarter. Nevertheless, short-term interbank rates in 2016 generally remained below the Base Rate.

In response to the increase in the target range for the US federal funds rate on December 14 (US time) from 0.25–0.50% to 0.50–0.75%, the Base Rate was raised from 0.75% to 1.00% on December 15. The adjustment to the Base Rate was made in accordance with the revised calculation formula announced on March 26, 2009. According to this formula, the Base Rate is set at the higher of (i) the lower end of the target range for the US federal funds rate plus 50 basis points, or (ii) the average of the five-day moving averages of the overnight and one-month Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rates (HIBOR).

Chart 3: 2016 Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rates

In January, forward points for the Hong Kong dollar exhibited a significant premium, broadly tracking the interest rate differential between the Hong Kong dollar and the US dollar, and partly reflecting investors’ demand for FX hedging of their Hong Kong equity portfolios (see Chart 4). The forward premium began to narrow in February. As market conditions stabilized, forward points for the Hong Kong dollar remained generally stable from March to November, before rising again in December as the interest rate differential between the Hong Kong dollar and the US dollar narrowed. Overall, the Hong Kong money market operated smoothly, with ample interbank liquidity. Discount window borrowing was not active in 2016, involving only HK$5.3 billion.

# Linked Exchange Rate System

Despite having weathered numerous regional and global financial crises, the Linked Exchange Rate System (the Linked Rate System) has remained the cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability for decades. The heightened market volatility at the beginning of 2016 once again sparked commentary regarding the weakening of the Hong Kong dollar and comparisons to the Asian Financial Crisis. To enhance public understanding of the Linked Rate System, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) explained the technical details of the system to the public and pointed out that Hong Kong’s financial system is capable of withstanding shocks. The Government also reiterated its firm commitment to maintaining the Linked Rate System. The stability of the foreign exchange and money markets further consolidated public confidence in the Government’s determination to uphold the Linked Rate System and in the Hong Kong dollar as a means of payment and store of value. During its annual Article IV consultation with Hong Kong, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) explicitly stated that the Linked Rate System is the most suitable monetary regime for Hong Kong, noting that Hong Kong’s flexible economic structure, ample fiscal and reserve buffers, and robust and effective financial supervision provide strong support for the system.

Chart 4: 2016 US Dollar/Hong Kong Dollar Forward Points

Given that a sound banking system is crucial to the proper functioning of the Linked Rate System, the HKMA continued to closely monitor banks’ credit, liquidity, and interest rate risk management, as well as the results of stress tests. The HKMA also strengthened supervision of banks’ personal, corporate, and Mainland-related lending to ensure that the banking system is equipped to cope with shocks. In the face of US monetary policy normalization, Hong Kong interbank offered rates began to rise. The HKMA reminded the public to remain alert and to be well-prepared for possible market volatility and risks.

To enhance the transparency of the Currency Board accounts, since October 1998, a portion of the Exchange Fund’s assets has been designated as backing for the monetary base. The Backing Ratio (i.e., the ratio of backing assets to the monetary base) fluctuated within a narrow range of 106.3% to 107.5% in 2016, without reaching either the upper or lower limits. As at December 31, 2016, the ratio stood at 106.7% (see Chart 5). Under the Linked Rate System, although certain Exchange Fund assets have been designated as the backing portfolio, all assets of the Exchange Fund may be used to support the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate. The substantial financial resources of the Exchange Fund provide a strong backing for Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability in the face of sudden shocks.

Chart 5: Daily Movements of the Backing Ratio in 2016

# Research Work

The Currency Board Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for monitoring and examining issues related to Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability. In 2016, topics explored by the Currency Board Committee included the synchronization of economic growth between Hong Kong, Mainland China, and the United States, external demand for the Hong Kong dollar, and Hong Kong’s Financial Conditions Index. The minutes of the Currency Board Committee meetings and the reports on the operation of the Currency Board System submitted by the HKMA are available on the HKMA website.

The Hong Kong Institute for Monetary Research continued to support research in the areas of monetary policy, banking, and finance. In 2016, the Institute invited a total of 18 scholars for visits and published 20 working papers.

During the year, the Research Centre organized six international conferences and seminars, including:
- In January, the "7th Annual International Conference on the Chinese Economy" was held, with the theme "China's Growing Impact on the Global Economy." Eight research papers covering a wide range of topics were presented, including China's growth rebalancing and growth potential, economic spillover effects from China, the impact of the renminbi on the global and regional economies, as well as trends in carry trades and information flows among renminbi markets.
- In March, in collaboration with the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology and Keio University, the "HKUST-Keio-HKIMR Conference on Exchange Rates and Macroeconomics" was held, covering various economic topics such as global economic imbalances, exchange rate dynamics, capital controls, and monetary policy.
- In August, in partnership with City University of Hong Kong, the "Real Estate and Financial Stability Conference" was held. Papers presented at the conference covered topics such as age, demographics and housing demand; the impact of large investors on asset quality; dynamics of Hong Kong housing prices; housing market affordability; the impact of mortgage regulations on household lifecycle homeownership decisions; and the residential property market in Mainland China.
- In October, together with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Bank for International Settlements, a seminar on Asia-Pacific economic systems was held, themed "Resilience of Regional Economic Systems in a Turbulent Global Environment." The seminar attracted senior central bank officials, leading academics, and experts from international organizations and private institutions, who engaged in interactive roundtable discussions on the most pressing issues facing Asia-Pacific economic systems. Topics discussed were wide-ranging, including financial imbalances in Asia, capital flows, spillover effects of Mainland China's economic slowdown on other regional economies, as well as the impact and outlook for Asia's potential growth.

The Research Centre also held the "14th Annual Summer Workshop" in August and the "14th Mainland China Economic Conference" in September, focusing on asset quality and financial stability issues in Mainland banks. These conferences and seminars attracted participants from academia, the financial services sector, and central banks from various regions. During the year, the Research Centre also organized 21 public seminars on a wide range of economic, monetary, and financial topics.

# Banknotes and Coins

As at the end of 2016, the total value of circulating banknotes (i.e., banknotes issued by note-issuing banks) was HK$407.8 billion, an increase of 13.2% over the previous year (Figures 6, 7, and 8). The total value of government-issued circulating banknotes and coins was HK$11.8 billion, an increase of 5.3% over the previous year (Figures 9 and 10). Among the government-issued banknotes and coins, the total value of HK$10 circulating banknotes was HK$4.4 billion, of which polymer banknotes accounted for 86%.
